a)used to say you think something is true, although you are uncertain about it
b)used when agreeing to let someone do something, especially when you do not really want to
c)used when saying in an angry way that you expect something is true
d)used to say that you think that something is probably true, although you wish it was not and hope someone will tell you it is not

examples.text: I suppose (that)

‘Aren’t you pleased?’ ‘Yes, I suppose so.’
‘Can we come with you?’ ‘Oh, I suppose so.’

I suppose (that)

definition.text:

examples.text: I don’t suppose you have any idea where my address book is, do you?

definition.text: used when talking about a possible condition or situation, and then imagining the result

definition.text:
a)used to say what someone should or should not do, especially because of rules or what someone in authority has said
b)used to say what was or is expected or intended to happen, especially when it did not happen
c)used to say that something is believed to be true by many people, although it might not be true or you might disagree

meaning.translation: (مثلاً : چه زمانی قراره اونجا باشی؟ یا مثلاً: من قرار نیست در مورد این موضوع با کسی حرف بزنم)قراره

examples.text: We’re supposed to check out of the hotel by 11 o'clock.
I’m not supposed to tell anyone.

No one was supposed to know about it.
The meeting was supposed to take place on Tuesday, but we’ve had to postpone it.
The new laws are supposed to prevent crime.
The castle is supposed to be haunted.

Mrs Carver is supposed to have a lot of money.

definition.text: the top part of your body that has your face at the front and is supported by your neck

definition.text: a serious disagreement that divides an organization or group of people into smaller groups

examples.text: split in/within
The argument could lead to a damaging split in the party.
a deep split within the government

The union is desperate to avoid a split over this issue.

examples.text: rumours of a marriage split

She seems to be getting over her recent split with her fiancé.

definition.text: the way in which something, especially money, is shared between several people

examples.text: In a publishing deal, the average split used to be 50:50 between writer and publisher.

definition.text: a clear separation or difference between two things

title: split_verb_1

definition.text: if a group of people splits, or if it is split, people in the group disagree strongly with each other and the group sometimes divides into separate smaller groups

examples.text: It was feared that the issue would split the church.
be split on/over something
The party is split over the issue of immigration.
The government appears deeply split on this issue.
split from
The Pan-Africanist Congress split from the ANC in 1959.
split something in two/down the middle
The war has split the nation in two.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle split, present participle splitting )
title: split_verb_2

definition.text: to divide or separate something into different parts or groups, or to be divided into different parts or groups

examples.text: split into
Can you split into groups of three now?
split something into something
The book is split into six sections.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle split, present participle splitting )
title: split_verb_3

definition.text: if something splits, or if you split it, it tears or breaks along a straight line

examples.text: The branch split under their weight.
One of the boxes had split open.
split (something) in two/half
The board had split in two.
Split the pineapple down the middle.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle split, present participle splitting )
title: split_verb_4

examples.text: split something between somebody/something
Profits will be split between three major charities.

He agreed to sell the car and split the proceeds with his brother.
split something three/four etc ways(= share something between three, four etc people or groups )

We agreed to split the cost.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle split, present participle splitting )
title: split_verb_5

definition.text: to make someone’s head or lip have a cut in it, as a result of a fall or hit

examples.text: She fell against a table and split her lip.

title: split_verb_6

meaning.translation: جدا شدن (پایان دادن به یک رابطه یا ازدواج)

He split from his wife last year.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle split, present participle splitting )
title: split_verb_7

examples.text: Come on – let’s split.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle split, present participle splitting )
title: split_verb_8

definition.text: to argue that there is a difference between two things, when the difference is really too small to be important

examples.text: This is just splitting hairs.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle split, present participle splitting )
title: split_verb_9

definition.text: to agree on an amount that is exactly between two amounts that have been mentioned

examples.text: OK, let’s split the difference, and I’ll give you £20.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle split, present participle splitting )

Social issues figured prominently in the talks.

examples.text: We need to win the next three games. It’s a big ask, but I’m confident we can do it.

ask somebody for something
He repeatedly asked Bailey for the report.
ask (somebody) if/whether you can do something

examples.text: How much is he asking?

definition.text: to invite someone to your home, to go out with you etc

examples.text: Saying that to a feminist is just asking for trouble.

examples.text: You have to ask yourself where your responsibilities really lie.

examples.text: ‘Where’s she gone then?’ ‘Don’t ask me!’
